resource.name: Municipal Property Tax Rates
resource.description: The dataset is a list of property tax rates that are applicable in each municipality in the Province. These rates are applied to property assessment (based on market value) which can change from year to year. The convention is to express the tax rate as per $100 of assessment e.g., Amherst's residential rate is $1.63 per $100 of assessment.

domain_metadata.value: This information has been gathered from Statement of Estimate Reports as submitted to the Province by municipalities. The municipalities are required to submit this informaiton to the Province by Sepember 30th of each year.  Municipalities may also have additional area rates for special services on top of the general rate. Users are cautioned these tax rates are for general reference only, for official rates please contact the appropriate Municipality.   The Cape Breton Suburban rate is an average of 8 various rural suburban tax rates within the county of Cape Breton.    Effective April 1st, 2020, the Town of Windsor and the Municipality of West Hants have consolidated into a regional municipality, West Hants Regional Municipality.
Annually from each fiscal year, from 09-10 to 20-21 (April 1, 2009 to March 31, 2021)

resource.name: Industry Specialization based on Employment by Functional Economic Regions
resource.description: The dataset provides information on industry specialization, industry structure and employment for Nova Scotia’s Functional Economic Regions.  The data fields include: Functional Economic Region Name, North American Industry Classification (NAICS) - 4-digits; Category and Type of Industry; Location Quotient by Employment; and Level of Specialization category.  Fields may be updated or change over time.
columns_description: Level of Specialization
North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) - 4 digits
Location Quotient based on Employment
Functional Economic Region Name

domain_metadata.value: PDFs of Regional Profiles of Nova Scotia's Functional Regions can be found at https://data.novascotia.ca/Business-and-Industry/Industry-Specialization-based-on-Business-Location/cyje-iisx

Industry specialization can be measured using Location Quotients (LQ) that compare the regional share of employment in an industry with the national share of employment in the same industry.  An LQ greater than 1 suggests the number of employment in an industry is more concentrated in the region than it is nationally.  An LQ greater than 2 indicates a very high level of specialization or concentration, 1.25 to 2 indicates a high specialization; an LQ close to 1 (0.75-1.25) indicates an average specialization; and less than 0.75 indicates a low specialization.  An LQ of 0 for a particular industry means that no employment in that particular industry exists in the region according to the Census.
Employment is based on those who reported employment income in 2015.

resource.name: [ARCHIVED] Nova Scotia Groundwater Observation Well Temperature Data
resource.description: [ARCHIVED] Recommendation is to discontinue the “Nova Scotia Groundwater Observation Well Temperature Data”. This is for scientific / technical reasons. The data was never designed to be collected as a dataset on its own, but is used by sensors to create a correction facter for other data (groundwater levels). Developments in academic research show that the type of water wells we monitor for groundwater levels do not have the correct design for measuring temperature, with issues that include the potential within wells for thermal convection cells that cause groundwater temperature readings to fluctuate inconsistently. Groundwater temperatures have been recorded from the NS Groundwater Observation Well monitoring network since 2003. This temperature data is presented as daily averages and may be influenced by a number of variable factors including air temperature, well construction, depth, geology and groundwater conditions.

resource.name: [Archived] Trade Mission or International Engagement
resource.description: [ARCHIVED] The Province of Nova Scotia recognizes the importance of foreign engagement and regularly engages in government to government and government to business relations globally. In order to ensure that effective and positive international government relations are developed and maintained, the Nova Scotia Department of Intergovernmental Affairs has been mandated to foster and promote intergovernmental /international relations globally. Developing and enhancing meaningful intergovernmental/international relationships is an incremental process. Intergovernmental/international relations can be achieved through a number of primary activities: out-bound trade and business missions; incoming trade and business missions; and Nova Scotia government to foreign government/foreign business promotion. Mission reports are a key accounting of government activity and reflect the various specific events and key follow up activities.

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The attached 20210315_Queens_County_Current_Data_Deployment_Details contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique ID which can be used to filter and separate individual data sets for export from the Open Data Portal.   Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) consist of time-series measurements of ocean current speed and direction collected in vertical profile through the water column and divided into measurement cells of specified size.  These readings are arranged from top to bottom in chronological order and from left to right in order of cell distances from the face of the instrument. For example: the column WaterSpeed_1 contains data collected in the cell nearest to the instrument. The exact location of individual cells within the water column is a function of the altitude of the instrument above the sea floor, the specified size of the individual cells and the blanking distance of the instrument in its current configuration.  These attributes for a given dataset can be found in the attached 20210315_Queens_County_Current_Data_Deployment_Details.  Each individual row of data (Ensemble) presents speed and direction measurements for each measurement cell that have been averaged from multiple individual measurements (Pings) over a specified time period (Averaging Interval).  The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements), the Averaging Interval and the Number of Pings averaged can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. domain_metadata.value: Chart (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Antigonish-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average/d6fb-k8yz) and Coastal Monitoring Program Report: Antigonish County (https://cmar.ca/2020/07/14/coastal-monitoring-program/)

The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) measures essential ocean variables throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters as part of the Coastal Monitoring Program. This program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in 2012 and CMAR became involved in 2017. CMAR collects water quality data (temperature, dissolved oxygen, and intermittent salinity) using autonomous sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or dragging.  The Coastal Monitoring Program data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the WATERBODY, STATION, DEPTH, VARIABLE, and/or TIMESTAMP of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Antigonish-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average/d6fb-k8yz).   Water Quality Data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/2020/07/14/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server t

resource.name: Nominee Certificates Issued by Stream
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Certificates are issued in particular streams of the Nominee Program, and each stream has different eligibility criteria. Over time, streams may close as new streams are developed. This dataset provides the number of certificates issued annually by the streams under which the nomination was made.

See https://novascotiaimmigration.com/move-here/ for information on current streams.

The maximum number of nomination certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The attached 20210315_Annapolis_County_Current_Speed_and Direction_Data contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique ID which can be used to filter and separate individual data sets for export from the Open Data Portal.   Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) consist of time-series measurements of ocean current speed and direction collected in vertical profile through the water column and divided into measurement cells of specified size.  These readings are arranged from top to bottom in chronological order and from left to right in order of cell distances from the face of the instrument. For example: the column WaterSpeed_1 contains data collected in the cell nearest to the instrument. The exact location of individual cells within the water column is a function of the altitude of the instrument above the sea floor, the specified size of the individual cells and the blanking distance of the instrument in its current configuration.  These attributes for a given dataset can be found in the attached 20210315_Annapolis_County_Current_Speed_and Direction_Data.  Each individual row of data (Ensemble) presents speed and direction measurements for each measurement cell that have been averaged from multiple individual measurements (Pings) over a specified time period (Averaging Interval).  The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements), the Averaging Interval and the Number of Pings averaged can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. resource.name: Municipal Land Use Planning Comprehensiveness
resource.description:
This dataset provides information about the extent of municipal land use planning in Nova Scotia. Each municipality is listed along with the type of its land use planning described as either comprehensive for entire municipality, comprehensive for local areas only, comprehensive for towns, or single issue.  It also lists the date of the municipal land use plans described. 

A comprehensive strategy is one that address all major areas of concern, for example: residential, commercial, industrial, recreational, environmental, social and economic. A single-issue plan only deals with specific land-use issues such as wind turbines, drinking water protection, general development. Municipal planning strategies may be developed for an entire municipality and/or a local area within its jurisdiction.

resource.name: Age of Nominees at Time of Application
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa.

Nominees must generally be between the ages of 21 to 55 at time of application, but the LSI reserves the right to waive this criteria in exceptional circumstances. This dataset provides the number of certificates issued annually by age range. 

The maximum number of certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

resource.name: Innovacorp Start-Up Acceleration Initiative Awards
resource.description:
Innovacorp is Nova Scotia's early stage venture capital organization. It works to find, fund and foster innovative Nova Scotia start-ups that strive to change the world. The goal is to help those start-ups commercialize their technologies and succeed in the global marketplace. Target industries include information technology, life sciences, clean technology and ocean technology. 

Early stage investment is at the core of Innovacorp’s business model. The team also gives entrepreneurs access to world-class incubation facilities, expert advice and other support to help accelerate their companies. 

This dataset includes data on Innovacorp's major acceleration program awards for Nova Scotia start-ups.

resource.name: Municipal Financial Capacity and Town Foundation Grants
resource.description:
Municipal Financial Capacity Grant is a legislated unconditional operating grant to assist municipalities whose costs of delivering a core set of services exceed their ability to pay, when compared to similar municipalities. In addition, towns are provided with a $50,000 Town Foundation Grant as recognition of the particular challenges they face due to local road responsibilities and assessment bases. Prior to 2019, the Municipal Financial Capacity Grant was called 'Equalization Grant'. 
The Municipial Grants Act (S.8, s.19A) provides for the payment of the Municipal Financial Capacity Grant and the Town Foundation Grant, which are in the form of unconditional transfers.

domain_metadata.value: Chart (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Shelburne-County-Daily-/5ech-4c5t) and Coastal Monitoring Program Report: Yarmouth County (https://cmar.ca/2020/07/14/coastal-monitoring-program/)

The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) measures essential ocean variables throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters as part of the Coastal Monitoring Program. This program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in 2012 and CMAR became involved in 2017. CMAR collects water quality data (temperature, dissolved oxygen, and intermittent salinity) using autonomous sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or dragging.  The Coastal Monitoring Program data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the WATERBODY, STATION, DEPTH, VARIABLE, and/or TIMESTAMP of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Shelburne-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average-/5ech-4c5t). Water Quality Data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The station location dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/dhns-eqjr) contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique Deployment ID which can be used to filter and separate individual datasets for export from the Open Data Portal. Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs), Xeos wind-wave buoys, and MarineLabs wind-wave buoys consist of time-series measurements of significant wave height, wave period, and average wave direction. Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. Note that some observations of 0m wave height may reflect false zero recordings, and analyses should be conducted accordingly. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the ADCPs presents wave height (significant, maximum, height average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in metres, and period (peak, maximum, period average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in seconds. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the wind-wave buoys presents wave height (significant, maximum) in metres and average wave direction in degrees relative to true north, corrected for localized magnetic declination specific to the deployment coordinates. The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements) can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. Date and time data are in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

domain_metadata.value: Data are current as of June 5, 2022 (when data for 2020 onward were updated as necessary). Rate data for 2021 will be added next month (May 2022). Data are extracted from a live database environment and are provisional and subject to change. Some case investigations in recent years remain ongoing. NS totals may be greater than sum of zones, as totals include cases from out of province and a small proportion where location of residence is under investigation.  Data include NSMES cases for which manner of death was determined to be suicide and recorded as suicide on the Medical Certificate of Death by the Medical Examiner.   Data for recent months and for the previous year are preliminary and counts and associated rates are likely to increase as case investigations are completed. Case review found that >90% of suicide deaths excluding those caused by drug toxicity were certified post-autopsy, which occurs within days of a reported death. Acccordingly, monitoring of suicide excluding drug toxicity provides a largely accurate, timely indicator of non-drug toxicity suicide. As such, counts of deaths by suicide excluding drug toxicity deaths is provided in addition to counts of total suicide deaths. Indicators of probable and confirmed drug toxicity deaths (including accident and suicide deaths) are also available on the data.novascotia.ca site for concurrent monitoring.  Data provided here may differ from Vital Statistics data sources due to differences in reporting timeframes (e.g. a death certified as suicide may appear under the 'not elsewhere classified' classification if the death was not certified by the time of data submission for a particular report.  Geocoding of address data has resulted in reclassification of zone of residence for a small number of cases (compared to prior releases of data). Population data have been updated with the most recent available data from Statistics Canada (17-10-0134-01; rate data may differ slightly from previous releases).

resource.name: Marriage Bonds 1763-1864; Marriage Registrations 1864-1945
resource.description: Civil registration of marriages in Nova Scotia began in 1758, with the introduction of procedures for obtaining a marriage license. The license was optional, surviving records are incomplete, and 'calling the banns' remained the preferred procedure for formalizing the marriage ritual. The parallel custom of posting a Marriage Bond, in addition to taking out a license, also dates from this early period. The bond was an optional adjunct which served to indicate the absence of legal impediments to the intended marriage; an incomplete series of these bonds exists for the years 1763-1864. Mandatory civil registration of marriages began in 1864 and has continued since, although compliance was not universal throughout the province until the early 20th century.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Minimum Wage
resource.description: Provincial regulations establish the province’s minimum wage. Minimum wage is the lowest legal wage employers can pay their employees. This dataset includes minimum wage rates in Nova Scotia dating back to 2002. Employers, employees and the public request minimum wage data, including in relation to historical rates.

domain_metadata.value: Between 1958 and 1965, minimum wage was set at a weekly - rather than hourly - rate and was based on where the work was performed (provincial zones). From 1965 to 1971, hourly minimum wages rates were set based on age, experience, sex and provincial zones. From 1972 until 1992 hourly minimum wage rates were set based on age and experience. Starting in 1993, age was removed as a factor in setting the minimum wage, which resulted in experienced and inexperienced rates being set until  April 1, 2020 when the inexperienced rate was eliminated leaving just one minimum wage rate.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Examination Results by year and board - Français 10
resource.description: Provides examination results for Reading (scaled score and performance level) and Writing (performance level for four components of writing) for each year examination has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the examinations.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of July 28, 2021. Assessments were not administered for 2016-2017 school year. French (CSAP) program students enrolled in Français 10 courses write this examination in January or June. French Immersion students do not write this examination.  For the reading portion, students read different types of texts and answered questions about what they read. Students also completed two writing tasks. Student performance in writing was reported for the four components: Ideas, Organization, Language Use and Conventions. Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) Level 4 (above the expectation). Students also received a scaled score in reading (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800). Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to develop this examination and to set the expectation of the examination. The expectation is what students should know and be able to do at the end of the course.

resource.name: NS Correctional Services Expenditures
resource.description: The financial expenditures of Correctional Services is an indicator of the resources required to administer custodial and community-based sentences in the province. This dataset provides financial information such as the gross expenditures on Nova Scotia Corrections; the per capita expenditures on Nova Scotia Corrections, which is calculated using the total population in Nova Scotia; and the average daily cost in adult custody in Nova Scotia, which is calculated using the adult offender population in adult facilities. Fluctuations in the cost of Corrections may be driven by a number of factors, including but not limited to: the level of crime, legislative and policy responses to crime, sentencing practices, and administrative changes relating to organizational structure and the delivery of services, as well as changes in salaries and benefits for staff. The source for the financial information is the Nova Scotia Department of Justice, Financial Services Corporate Service Unit (CSU). Population data is sourced from Statistics Canada CANSIM Table 051-0005 - Estimates of population, Canada, provinces and territories.

domain_metadata.value: Corrections in Nova Scotia: Key Indicators URL: http://www.novascotia.ca/just/publications/docs/2015-16_corrections_key_indicator_report.pdf and Nova Scotia Department of Justice Accountability Report URL: http://novascotia.ca/just/publications/

resource.name: Innovacorp Venture Capital Investments
resource.description:
Innovacorp is Nova Scotia's early stage venture capital organization. It works to find, fund and foster innovative Nova Scotia start-ups that strive to change the world. The goal is to help those start-ups commercialize their technologies and succeed in the global marketplace. Target industries include information technology, life sciences, clean technology and ocean technology. 

Early stage investment is at the core of Innovacorp’s business model. The team also gives entrepreneurs access to world-class incubation facilities, expert advice and other support to help accelerate their companies.

Innovacorp makes equity investments through the Nova Scotia First Fund, a venture capital fund backed by the Nova Scotia government. Venture capital-backed start-ups typically have a greater economic impact than their non-backed peers, demonstrating stronger growth in revenue, employment and assets. Innovacorp, however, is ultimately driven by generating financial returns on its fund, and also seeks to leverage its deals with other venture capital and angel co-investors, attracting new capital and expertise for the region.

resource.name: Innovacorp Incubation Resident Companies
resource.description:
Innovacorp is Nova Scotia's early stage venture capital organization. It works to find, fund and foster innovative Nova Scotia start-ups that strive to change the world. The goal is to help those start-ups commercialize their technologies and succeed in the global marketplace. Target industries include information technology, life sciences, clean technology and ocean technology. 

Early stage investment is at the core of Innovacorp’s business model. The team also gives entrepreneurs access to world-class incubation facilities, expert advice and other support to help accelerate their companies.

Innovacorp manages three incubation facilities which are home to more than two dozen companies employing hundreds of entrepreneurs and skilled professionals. The Technology Innovation Centre (TIC) in Dartmouth targets companies in clean technology and a variety of other knowledge-based sectors, while the Innovacorp Enterprise Centre (IEC) on the Dalhousie University campus in Halifax focuses on companies in the life sciences sectors. Start-Up Yard at COVE (Centre for Ocean Ventures and Entrepreneurship) on the Dartmouth waterfront is for ocean technology ventures.

This dataset includes data on Innovacorp's 2018-2019 resident incubation companies.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of June 6, 2022. Some of Innovacorp’s incubation resident companies take space at the facilities for just a short time (i.e., six-months) as their residency is part of an Innovacorp program (e.g., Start-Up Visa Program, Accelerate Program).

resource.name: Citizenship of Nominees
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Applicants are attracted to the Nova Scotia Nominee Program from around the world. This dataset provides the number of nomination certificates issued annually by citizenship of the applicant. 

The maximum number of nomination certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of Feb 7, 2022. A nomination by the Province of Nova Scotia does not guarantee that the applicant will become a permanent resident. The federal government has the final decision on who receives permanent residency and is admissible to Canada based on various considerations that include, but are not limited to, health, criminality and security checks.

resource.name: Queens County Water Quality Data
resource.description: Oceanographic data from sensor strings deployed in Queens County as part of the Centre for Marine Applied Research's (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program.
columns_description: waterbody in which the string was deployed
timestamp of the measurement (in UTC)
model and serial number of the sensor that recorded the measurement

parameter measured (Temperature, Dissolved Oxygen, or Salinity)
if the string was deployed on an aquaculture lease area, the lease number (NA otherwise)

indicates whether the string was attached to a fixed (does not move vertically with the tide) or floating mooring

domain_metadata.value: Chart (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Queens-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average-Val/twbe-dv9i) and Coastal Monitoring Program Report: Queens County (https://cmar.ca/2020/07/14/coastal-monitoring-program/)

The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) measures essential ocean variables throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters as part of the Coastal Monitoring Program. This program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in 2012 and CMAR became involved in 2017. CMAR collects water quality data (temperature, dissolved oxygen, and intermittent salinity) using autonomous sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or dragging.  The Coastal Monitoring Program data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the WATERBODY, STATION, DEPTH, VARIABLE, and/or TIMESTAMP of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Queens-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average-Val/twbe-dv9i). Water Quality Data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/2020/07/14/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server thr

resource.name: Film Industry Tax Credit – Approved Tax Credits
resource.description: Public record for the Film Industry Tax Credit containing information from approved Part A and Part B applications across all corporations. Information includes company name, parent company name, production title, application type (Part A or B), amount of credit provided (or sought if Part A), approval date.
columns_name:
Amount of Credit Provided 
(or Sought if Part A)

domain_metadata.value: Productions are added to the list after a Part A / Part B application is approved. Part A applications, which are not mandatory, determine whether a production is eligible for the tax credit and uses the production's budget to calculate an estimated tax credit amount the corporation may receive. Part B applications are mandatory and determine whether a production is eligible for the tax credit and uses actual spending to calculate a tax credit amount. Once a Part B application is approved, a tax credit certificate is issued and the corporation can claim the tax credit on their corporate income tax return. The Film Industry Tax Credit has been replaced by the Digital Animation Tax Credit and the Nova Scotia Film & Television Production Incentive Fund.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Assessment Results by Year and Board - Mathématiques en 8e année
resource.description: Provides assessment results for Mathematics (scaled score and performance level) for each year assessment has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the assessments.

domain_metadata.value: French program (CSAP) Grade 8 students write this assessment in June. Students answered questions in each of the mathematics strands (le nombre; les régularités et les relations; la mesure et la géométrie; et les statistiques et les probabilités). Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) and Level 4 (above the expectation).Students also received a scaled score in mathematics (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800).  Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to develop this assessment and to set the performance expectation, which is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the end of grade 8.

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The attached 20210315_Shelburne_County_Current_Data_Deployment_Details contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique ID which can be used to filter and separate individual data sets for export from the Open Data Portal.   Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) consist of time-series measurements of ocean current speed and direction collected in vertical profile through the water column and divided into measurement cells of specified size.  These readings are arranged from top to bottom in chronological order and from left to right in order of cell distances from the face of the instrument. For example: the column WaterSpeed_1 contains data collected in the cell nearest to the instrument. The exact location of individual cells within the water column is a function of the altitude of the instrument above the sea floor, the specified size of the individual cells and the blanking distance of the instrument in its current configuration.  These attributes for a given dataset can be found in the attached 20210315_Shelburne_County_Current_Data_Deployment_Details.  Each individual row of data (Ensemble) presents speed and direction measurements for each measurement cell that have been averaged from multiple individual measurements (Pings) over a specified time period (Averaging Interval).  The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements), the Averaging Interval and the Number of Pings averaged can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The station location dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/dhns-eqjr) contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique Deployment ID which can be used to filter and separate individual datasets for export from the Open Data Portal. Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs), Xeos wind-wave buoys, and MarineLabs wind-wave buoys consist of time-series measurements of significant wave height, wave period, and average wave direction. Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. Note that some observations of 0m wave height may reflect false zero recordings, and analyses should be conducted accordingly. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the ADCPs presents wave height (significant, maximum, height average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in metres, and period (peak, maximum, period average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in seconds. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the wind-wave buoys presents wave height (significant, maximum) in metres and average wave direction in degrees relative to true north, corrected for localized magnetic declination specific to the deployment coordinates. The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements) can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. Date and time data are in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

resource.name: [ARCHIVED] Select Nova Scotia
resource.description: [ARCHIVED] The Select Nova Scotia program has ended and the data contained in this dataset is no longer being collected. Select Nova Scotia is a program developed by the Province of Nova Scotia to encourage Nova Scotians to shop and buy locally. Select Nova Scotia promotions and campaigns and the web site raise consumer awareness about Nova Scotia agri-food and seafood products, and other locally made goods.

domain_metadata.value: Archived on May 27, 2022. The Select Nova Scotia program has ended and the data contained in this dataset is no longer being collected. Much of the information is from businesses that have registered, self-identified as producers and sellers of local food, craft and artisan products.  However, the orignial web site was populated from an existing database. Some errors and inaccuracies are still present in both the old dataset and newly registered. If businesses are not diligent about updating their profile, errors may exist.  We will be requiring all current members to update their profile yearly, and will be removing profiles that do not meet our newly instated web site guidelines: To be eligible to register on the Select Nova Scotia website, your business must: have its head office in Nova Scotia; produce, harvest or sell Nova Scotia products; if a restaurant, be a member in good standing of Taste of Nova Scotia.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Assessment Results by Year and Board - Reading and Writing in Grade 8
resource.description: Provides assessment results for Reading (scaled score and performance level) and Writing (performance level for four components of writing) for each year assessment has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the assessments.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of July 28, 2021. Assessments were not administered for 2016-2017 school year. English program Grade 8 students, including French Immersion, write this assessment in June. For the reading portion of the assessment, students read different types of texts and answered questions about what they read. For the writing portion of the assessment, students completed two writing tasks. Student performance in writing was reported for the four components: Ideas, Organization, Language Use and Conventions. Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) Level 4 (above the expectation). Students also received a scaled score in reading (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800). Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to build this assessment, score the writing tasks and set the performance expectations in Reading and Writing. The expectation is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the end of grade 8.

resource.name: Events East Group Economic Impact
resource.description: This data set provides economic impact from two of Events East Group business groups: Halifax Convention Centre and Scotiabank Centre.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of November 7, 2020. All direct expenditures associated with Halifax Convention Centre are considered incremental. 27 per cent of Scotiabank Centre direct expenditures are incremental. Where there are missing values, the data is not available. With the transition to a new governance structure combined with operating both the World Trade and Convention Centre (WTCC) and the new Halifax Convention Centre during the fiscal year, 2017-18 represents an anomaly for the organization and is not comparable to past operations or indicative of future years. Events East Group began managing all operations of the former Trade Centre Limited (TCL) effective April 1, 2017, however, the financial cutover to Events East was triggered by achievement of substantial completion of the Halifax Convention Centre, which did not take place until March 1, 2018. For this reason, comparatives between Halifax Convention Centre and Convention Centre are not applicable.

domain_metadata.value: Chart (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Richmond-County-Daily-A/5p9y-iyag) and Coastal Monitoring Program Report: Richmond County (https://cmar.ca/2020/07/14/coastal-monitoring-program/)

The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) measures essential ocean variables throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters as part of the Coastal Monitoring Program. This program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in 2012 and CMAR became involved in 2017. CMAR collects water quality data (temperature, dissolved oxygen, and intermittent salinity) using autonomous sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or dragging.  The Coastal Monitoring Program data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the WATERBODY, STATION, DEPTH, VARIABLE, and/or TIMESTAMP of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Richmond-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average-V/5p9y-iyag). Water Quality Data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/2020/07/14/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server thr

resource.name: Nova Scotia Lake Chemistry Data
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Lake Survey program is a partnership initiative between the Department of Environment and Climate Change and the Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture to inventory lakes throughout the province determining baseline water quality, in support of both sport fisheries and water resource management areas.

The following weblink connects to a Department of Environment and Climate Change web map that includes the locations of the monitored lakes within the province and an alternative method for downloading the same lake chemistry dataset: http://nse.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7ded7a30bef44f848e8a4fc8672c89bd"

domain_tags: lakes; water bodies; chemistry; water resources management; fish; water quality

domain_metadata.value: Water quality samples are collected at approximately 10 different lakes per annum. The samples are submitted to the Nova Scotia Environmental Services Laboratory operated by the Nova Scotia Health Authority in Halifax, NS for analysis. Field parameters are measured using a multiparameter instrument. The following are the monitored water quality parameters and applicable measurement units: field temperature (°C), field dissolved oxygen (mg/L), Secchi disc depth (m), select metals (µg/L), calcium (mg/L), magnesium (mg/L), hardness as CaCO3 (mg/L), lab conductivity (umho/cm), lab pH (-), lab turbidity (-), alkalinity as CaCO3 (mg/L), chloride (mg/L), colour (TCU), silica (mg/L), sulphate (mg/L), total nitrogen (mg/L), nitrate and nitrite as N (mg/L), ammonia as N (mg/L), orthophosphorus as P, (mg/L), total phosphorus (mg/L), total suspended solids (mg/L), total organic carbon (mg/L), chlorophyll a (mg/m3) and pheophytin (µg/L).  Bathymetric maps have been produced for most of the sampled lakes and their attributes (surface area, volume, max & mean depths) are included in the dataset.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Assessment Results by Year and Board - Reading and Writing in Grade 3
resource.description: Provides assessment results for Reading (scaled score and performance level) and Writing (performance level for four components of writing) for each year assessment has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the assessments.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of March 5, 2018. English program Grade 3 students write this assessment on two days in late September/early October. French Immersion students do not write this assessment. For the reading portion of the assessment, students read different types of texts and answered questions about what they read. Individual student results were reported in three levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), and Level 3 and above (at or above the expectation). For the writing portion of the assessment, students completed two writing tasks. Student performance in writing was reported for the four components Ideas, Organization, Language Use and Conventions in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) Level 4 (above the expectation). Students also received a scaled score in reading (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800).  Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to build this assessment, score the writing tasks and set the performance expectations in Reading and Writing. The expectation is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the beginning of grade 3.

resource.name: Crime Statistics - Crime Severity Index
resource.description: The dataset includes crime statistics at the provincial and police service levels. It is based on police reported incidents of crime reported through the Uniform Crime Reporting Survey (UCR). Statistics include the crime severity index, violent crime severity index, and non-violent crime severity index overall for provincial and police service levels. The Youth Crime Severity Index is based on the same principles as the overall Crime Severity Index, which reflects the seriousness of offences, but uses the number of youths accused instead of an incident count. Statistics included are: youth crime severity index, youth violent crime severity index and youth non-violent crime severity index for provincial level data only. This data is sourced from Statistics Canada through CANSIM.

domain_metadata.value: CANSIM Table 252-0075 Incident-based crime statistics, by detailed violations and police services, Atlantic provinces (http://www5.statcan.gc.ca/cansim/a26?lang=eng&id=2520075); CANSIM Table 252-0083 Crime severity index and weighted clearance rates, by police services, Atlantic provinces (http://www5.statcan.gc.ca/cansim/a26?lang=eng&id=2520083)

Current as of Feb 89 2022. 1) The Crime Severity Index is calculated using the Incident-based Uniform Crime Reporting Survey (UCR2) data. 2) The Youth Crime Severity Index is based on the same principles as the Overall Crime Severity Index, which reflects the relative seriousness of different offences, but uses the number of youths accused instead of an incident count. 3) During the production of each year's crime statistics, data from the previous year are revised to reflect any updates or changes that have been received from the police services. 4) The crime severity index includes all Criminal Code violations including traffic, as well as drug violations and all Federal Statutes. 5) The violent crime severity index includes all Incident-based Uniform Crime Reporting Survey (UCR2) violent violations. 6) The non-violent crime severity index includes all non-violent Criminal Code violations including traffic, as well as drug violations and all Federal Statutes 7) Where data is unavailable, the cell has been marked by "..".

resource.name: Old Forest Policy
resource.description: Forest stands identified under the Nova Scotia Old Forest Policy.

domain_metadata.value: The old forest policy layer of the GIS maps the locations of stands that were selected under the Old Forest Policy of 2012 (https://novascotia.ca/natr/library/forestry/reports/Old-Forest-Policy-2012.pdf). The forests identified in the layer consist of old growth stands, as well as mature stands set aside to restore old growth. According to the policy these stands will be maintained, and left to mature naturally with no management intervention. Most of the forests in this layer are not yet old growth. The majority are mature climax stands that provide good opportunities for long-term old growth restoration. The Old Forest Policy set out the procedures to, prioritizing all known old growth stands, then identifying stands that are good opportunities for old growth restoration in protected areas first, then selecting restoration opportunities on crown land outside of protected areas. True old growth forests are uncommon, and make up only a small proportion of the stands in this layer.  Forest stands within protected areas were evaluated to identify gaps (short-fall) for achieving the Old Forest Policy target of old growth and the best old forest restoration opportunities on at least eight percent of publicly owned forest land in each of the province’s 38 forested ecodistricts. Management restrictions, laws or regulations of forest stands within protected areas falls under each individual protected area’s legislation (i.e. Wilderness Area Protection Act, Special Places Protection Act, Provincial Parks Act, and Canada National Parks Act). The location of all old growth in the Province is unknown, however L&F maintains a registry of old stands that have been evaluated using L&F's Old Forest Scoring system (http://www.gov.ns.ca/natr/forestry/programs/ecosystems/scoresht.asp). Data is available for download in GDB format (https://nsgi.novascotia.ca/WSF_DDS/DDS.svc/DownloadFile?tkey=fhrTtdnDvfytwLz6&id=164) and SHP format (https://nsgi.novascotia.ca/WSF_DDS/DDS.svc/DownloadFile?tkey=fhrTtdnDvfytwLz6&id=85).

resource.name: Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network Grab Sample Water Quality Data
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Automated Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network was established in 2002 to assess water quality in surface waters across the province at five stations. In 2019 the station list was modified to reduce overlap with Environment and Climate Change Canada surface water quality monitoring stations. The results are used to help manage water resources, determine baseline water quality in lakes and watercourses throughout the province, evaluate the impact of human activities on surface water, and assess long term trends in water quality.

The following weblink connects to a Nova Scotia Department of Environment and Climate Change web map that includes the five monitoring station locations within the province and an alternative method for downloading the same datasets: http://nse.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7ded7a30bef44f848e8a4fc8672c89bd

domain_metadata.value: Starting in 2019 water quality samples are collected typically four times per year at five watercourse sites: Shelburne River at Pollard's Falls Bridge, East River at Plymouth Park Road, Kelley River at Eight Mile Ford, Southwest Margaree River near Upper Margaree and Salmon River at Murray. Prior to 2019, samples were collected at the following five sites: St Mary's River at Stillwater, Shelburne River at Pollard's Falls Bridge, Northeast Margaree River at Margaree Valley, Kelley River at Eight Mile Ford and LaHave River at West Northfield. The samples are submitted to the Nova Scotia Environmental Services Laboratory operated by the Nova Scotia Health Authority in Halifax, NS for analysis. Field parameters are measured using a Hydrolab multi-parameter probe. The following are the monitored water quality parameters and applicable measurement units: field temperature (°C), field pH (-), field conductivity (mmhos/cm), field dissolved oxygen (mg/L), field turbidity (NTU), select metals (µg/L), calcium (mg/L), magnesium (mg/L), hardness as CaCO3 (mg/L), lab conductivity (umho/cm), lab pH (-), lab turbidity (NTU), alkalinity as CaCO3 (mg/L), chloride (mg/L), colour (TCU), silica (mg/L), sulphate (mg/L), total nitrogen (mg/L), nitrate and nitrite as N (mg/L), ammonia as N (mg/L), orthophosphorus as P, (mg/L), total phosphorus (mg/L), total suspended solids (mg/L), total organic carbon (mg/L), chlorophyll a (mg/m3) and pheophytin (µg/L).  In 2019, additional metals and dissolved organic carbon (mg/L) were added to the lab parameter list.  Seven of the stations are located on watercourses and are co-located with Water Survey of Canada hydrometric stations. East River is located near a hydrometric/water level  station operated and maintained by the Town of Stellarton. Shelburne River, Northeast Margaree River, Kelley River and LaHave River stations are co-located with  automated Hydrolab water quality probes.

The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) measures environmental data throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters as part of the Coastal Monitoring Program. This program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in 2012 and CMAR became involved in 2017. CMAR collects temperature (degrees Celsius), dissolved oxygen (% saturation), and intermittent salinity (practical salinity units) data using autonomous sensors attached to moored lines, called ‘sensor strings’. Each string is attached to the seafloor by an anchored acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths. Sensor strings are typically deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour depending on the sensor. Data are retrieved by triggering the acoustic release, enabling the sensor string to float to the surface for data download. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes.   The Coastal Monitoring Program data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. We recommend using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the WATERBODY, STATION, DEPTH, VARIABLE, and/or TIMESTAMP of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Data-Digby-County-Daily/yeii-vbir).   Coastal Monitoring Program data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Coastal Monitoring Program: Station Locations" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/2020/07/14/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoin

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The station location dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/dhns-eqjr) contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique Deployment ID which can be used to filter and separate individual datasets for export from the Open Data Portal. Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs), Xeos wind-wave buoys, and MarineLabs wind-wave buoys consist of time-series measurements of significant wave height, wave period, and average wave direction. Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. Note that some observations of 0m wave height may reflect false zero recordings, and analyses should be conducted accordingly. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the ADCPs presents wave height (significant, maximum, height average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in metres, and period (peak, maximum, period average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in seconds. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the wind-wave buoys presents wave height (significant, maximum) in metres and average wave direction in degrees relative to true north, corrected for localized magnetic declination specific to the deployment coordinates. The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements) can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. Date and time data are in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) measures essential ocean variables throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters as part of the Coastal Monitoring Program. This program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in 2012 and CMAR became involved in 2017. CMAR collects water quality data (temperature, dissolved oxygen, and intermittent salinity) using autonomous sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or dragging.  The Coastal Monitoring Program data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the WATERBODY, STATION, DEPTH, VARIABLE, and/or TIMESTAMP of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Halifax-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average-Va/vpt7-apvp). Water Quality Data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/2020/07/14/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server thr

resource.name: Number of People Represented by Nominee Certificates
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills, and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Certificates are issued in particular streams of the Nominee Program, and each stream has different eligibility criteria. Over time, streams may close as new streams are developed. 

This dataset provides the number of certificates issued annually by the streams under which the nomination was made and the number of people expected to immigrate to Nova Scotia as a result of nominations in each stream.

See https://novascotiaimmigration.com/move-here/ for information on current streams.

The maximum number of nomination certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of February 7, 2022. A nomination by the Province of Nova Scotia does not guarantee that the applicant will become a permanent resident. resource.name: Agricultural Land Protection
resource.description:
This dataset provides information about how agricultural land is being protected through municipal land use planning. Each municipality is listed along with the level of agricultural land protection found within municipal land use plans. Agricultural protection is described as either exclusive zoning for agricultural land, agriculture identified as permitted use, or no planning for agriculture. 

Assessment of Agricultural Protection
Municipal planning strategies and land-use by-laws were assessed to determine the level of protection being given to agricultural land in the province. 
Three levels of protection have been identified through the planning document review:
1) Exclusive zoning for agricultural land meaning that agricultural land is identified and given a specific zoning with the intent of protecting agricultural land, activities and resources. 
2) Agriculture identified as a permitted use in other zones (rural residential, rural resource/development,industrial etc). Many of these zones have restrictions on certain agricultural uses, such as intensive livestock operations.
3) No planning for agriculture identifies municipalities that either do not have comprehensive municipal planning strategies or do not explicitly identify agriculture or agricultural activities within their planning strategies and land use bylaws.

domain_metadata.value: Data is a result of a scan done by Provincial planning employees but has not been vetted by the Municipalities.

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The attached 20210315_Victoria_County_Current_Data_Deployment_Details contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique ID which can be used to filter and separate individual data sets for export from the Open Data Portal.   Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) consist of time-series measurements of ocean current speed and direction collected in vertical profile through the water column and divided into measurement cells of specified size.  These readings are arranged from top to bottom in chronological order and from left to right in order of cell distances from the face of the instrument. For example: the column WaterSpeed_1 contains data collected in the cell nearest to the instrument. The exact location of individual cells within the water column is a function of the altitude of the instrument above the sea floor, the specified size of the individual cells and the blanking distance of the instrument in its current configuration.  These attributes for a given dataset can be found in the attached 20210315_Victoria_County_Current_Data_Deployment_Details.  Each individual row of data (Ensemble) presents speed and direction measurements for each measurement cell that have been averaged from multiple individual measurements (Pings) over a specified time period (Averaging Interval).  The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements), the Averaging Interval and the Number of Pings averaged can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment.
